detaileddescription.para: This glossary explains common terms you will see in the Retro Rocket user guide.

sect3.title: BASIC
sect3.para: A simple programming language that Retro Rocket uses for its programs. BASIC stands for “Beginner’s All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code.”

sect3.title: Command
sect3.para: A word you type at the shell prompt (for example dir, edit, up). Commands tell Retro Rocket to run a program or do something.

sect3.title: Directory
sect3.para: A folder that contains files or other folders. Example: /programs is a directory.

sect3.title: File system
sect3.para: The way files and directories are organised on a disk. Retro Rocket supports its own file system (RetroFS) as well as ISO 9660 and FAT32.

sect3.title: LiveCD
sect3.para: Running Retro Rocket directly from the CD without installing it to a hard disk. The system is read-only, but you get a temporary RAM disk to save your work.

sect3.title: Mount
sect3.para: Attaching a file system to a directory so you can use it. Example: mounting a disk at /ramdisk makes it available there.

sect3.title: Program
sect3.para: A file written in BASIC that Retro Rocket can run. Programs live in /programs.

sect3.title: Prompt
sect3.para: The > symbol you see in the shell where you type commands.

sect3.title: RAM disk
sect3.para: A temporary area of storage in memory, shown as /ramdisk. Fast, but everything is lost when you power off. Great for experiments and quick saves, but don’t trust it to keep your secrets after shutdown.

sect3.title: Shell
sect3.para: The text-based interface where you type commands. In Retro Rocket this is called rocketsh.

sect3.title: UEFI
sect3.para: Modern PCs use UEFI firmware instead of older BIOS. Retro Rocket boots on UEFI systems with standard graphics support.

sect3.title: Driver
sect3.para: A small program that teaches Retro Rocket how to talk to a piece of hardware (like a network card or sound chip). Drivers are usually loaded during startup.

sect3.title: DHCP
sect3.para: Short for Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol. A way for your computer to ask the network for its settings automatically (IP address, DNS, gateway). Default in Retro Rocket networking.

sect3.title: DNS
sect3.para: Short for Domain Name System. Translates easy names (like retro-rocket.net) into the numbers (IP addresses) that computers use to talk to each other.

sect3.title: Error
sect3.para: If something goes wrong, Retro Rocket will print an error message. Errors usually stop the current program, but you can always return to the shell prompt.

sect3.title: Rickroll
sect3.para: When Retro Rocket cheekily reminds you that you’re never gonna give it up. Type rick at the shell and enjoy pixel art + chiptune pop.

sect3.title: Pixel Art
sect3.para: Glorious blocky graphics that look like they were drawn with very large crayons. Retro Rocket uses these in demos and Easter eggs - not a bug, a feature.

sect3.title: Loopback
sect3.para: The special network address 127.0.0.1, which always points to your own machine. Useful for testing network programs locally.

sect3.title: Module
sect3.para: Another word for a loadable program or driver. Modules are often used to add extra features without changing the whole system.

sect3.title: Network interface
sect3.para: The connection point between Retro Rocket and the network (your network card or virtual adapter). Only one is supported at a time.

sect3.title: Prompt string
sect3.para: The text shown before the > in the shell. It can be changed by editing the variable PROMPT$.

sect3.title: RetroFS
sect3.para: The native Retro Rocket file system, designed for speed and simplicity on modern disks.

sect3.title: Static IP
sect3.para: A fixed network address you type in manually, instead of getting one automatically via DHCP.

sect3.title: Uptime
sect3.para: How long the system has been running since it was last started.
